In January 2025, shortly before his death, he donated approximately €200,000 of personal wealth to support a pasta-making project at a youth prison in Rome. ### Media Presence and Influence Despite his personal technological limitations, Francis achieved unprecedented media reach: - **Social Media:** He became the first pope to create an [Instagram account](/article/en/Instagram) (2016), gaining over one million followers in under 12 hours—a platform record at the time. - **Publications:** In 2024, he published *Hope: My Journey in History* (also titled *Life: My Story Through History*), an autobiography presented as "a historic publication" and the first memoirs published by a pope in office. - **Op-eds:** On 26 November 2020, he became the first pope to write an op-ed for [The New York Times](/article/en/The_New_York_Times), addressing COVID-19 and global solidarity. - **Cultural impact:** He was named [Time Magazine](/article/en/Time_Magazine) "Person of the Year" in 2013 and appeared on the cover of [Rolling Stone](/article/en/Rolling_Stone) in January 2014. He was included in [Forbes](/article/en/Forbes) "50 Greatest Leaders" and "Most Powerful People" lists. - **Speech patterns:** His homilies and public addresses, known for conversational tone and accessible language, generated regular media headlines for their directness on sensitive topics. ### Interests and Personality Francis maintained lifelong interests: - **Sports:** Passionate lifelong supporter of [San Lorenzo de Almagro](/article/en/San_Lorenzo_de_Almagro) football club; in 2014, when the team won the [Copa Libertadores](/article/en/Copa_Libertadores), Francis received them at his residence - **Literature and philosophy:** Admirer of [Jorge Luis Borges](/article/en/Jorge_Luis_Borges), [Fyodor Dostoevsky](/article/en/Fyodor_Dostoevsky), and [Romano Guardini](/article/en/Romano_Guardini) - **Opera and tango:** Enjoyed classical music and Argentine tango dancing - **Humor:** Known for spontaneous jokes and warmth in personal interactions, often catching people off-guard with his informality and accessibility ### Languages Francis was fluent in: - **Spanish** (native language) - **Italian** (the "everyday language" of the Holy See) - **Latin** (official language of the Church; though Vatican linguist [Wilfried Stroh](/article/en/Wilfried_Stroh) noted Francis would have struggled with fluent conversation) - **German** (fluent) - **French** (intermediate) - **Portuguese** (conversational) - **English** (limited) - **Ukrainian** and **Piedmontese** (some understanding) ## Health, Later Years, and Death ### Health Conditions and Hospitalizations Throughout his papacy, Francis faced increasing health challenges: **Early years:** He reported good health despite the lung surgery of his youth. **2021:** In July, he underwent [colon surgery](/article/en/Colon_surgery) at Gemelli Hospital for symptomatic diverticular stenosis, requiring a week's hospitalization. **2022:** He began using a wheelchair for public appearances due to persistent knee pain and sciatica, conditions that would plague him for the remainder of his life. **2023:** - March: Hospitalized with acute respiratory infection; discharged after a few days - June: Underwent abdominal wall surgery (laparotomy with hernia repair), remaining hospitalized for approximately two weeks **February–March 2025:** - On 14 February 2025, Francis entered Gemelli Hospital with bronchitis and a polymicrobial respiratory infection complicated by bilateral pneumonia - The Vatican described his condition as "critical"; he received blood transfusions and high-flow oxygen therapy - He was placed on non-invasive mechanical ventilation, experiencing two episodes of acute respiratory failure - On 23 March, after over a month of hospitalization, he was discharged; doctors recommended at least two months of home recovery - On 6 April, he appeared publicly for the first time since hospitalization, from his residence balcony - On 20 April (Easter Sunday), he appeared at the central loggia of [St. Peter's Basilica](/article/en/St_Peter's_Basilica), delivering his final Easter address and calling for Gaza ceasefire ### Last Public Appearance and Death On **20 April 2025** (Easter Sunday), Francis made his final public appearance from the central balcony of [St. Peter's Basilica](/article/en/St_Peter's_Basilica), delivering his Easter message and imparting the [Urbi et Orbi blessing](/article/en/Urbi_et_Orbi). In his address, he called for peace and ceasefire in Gaza and emphasized themes of resurrection and hope. On **21 April 2025** (Easter Monday), at approximately **7:35 AM** local time (UTC+2), Francis died at his residence in Domus Sanctae Marthae at age 88. The cause of death was a [stroke](/article/en/Stroke) leading to a coma and irreversible cardiovascular collapse. The announcement was made by [Cardinal Kevin Farrell](/article/en/Kevin_Farrell), the camerlengo (papal chamberlain), through a video statement on [Vatican News](/article/en/Vatican_News). ### Funeral and Burial The nine-day period of mourning ([novendiales](/article/en/Novendiales)) commenced following his death. His body lay in state at [St. Peter's Basilica](/article/en/St_Peter's_Basilica) from 23–25 April, during which approximately 250,000 people paid respects. On **26 April 2025**, a solemn funeral Mass was celebrated in [St. Peter's Square](/article/en/St_Peter's_Square), presided over by [Cardinal Giovanni Battista Re](/article/en/Giovanni_Battista_Re), dean of the [College of Cardinals](/article/en/College_of_Cardinals). Approximately 400,000 people participated—250,000 in the square and 150,000 along the funeral procession route through Rome. Following the funeral, his remains were carried in procession to the [Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore](/article/en/Basilica_of_Santa_Maria_Maggiore), where he was buried in accordance with his testament (dated 29 June 2022). He became the first pope since [Clement IX](/article/en/Clement_IX) (d. 1669) to be interred in Santa Maria Maggiore rather than in [St. Peter's](/article/en/St_Peter's_Basilica) or the [Vatican grottoes](/article/en/Papal_crypt). The burial reflected his deep devotion to the [Marian](/article/en/Mariology) invocation *Salus Populi Romani* ("Health of the Roman People"), whose icon is housed in that basilica. ### Testament In his spiritual testament (released upon his death), Francis repeated his wish to be buried in Santa Maria Maggiore and requested modest, simple funeral arrangements. The document ended: > "May the Lord grant a fitting reward to all those who have loved me and who continue to pray for me. The suffering that has marked the final part of my life, I offer to the Lord, for peace in the world and for fraternity among peoples." ## Papal Succession The 2025 conclave commenced on 7 May 2025. On **8 May 2025**, the cardinal electors elected [**Robert Francis Prevost**](/article/en/Robert_Francis_Prevost) as Francis's successor. Prevost, an American [Augustinian](/article/en/Augustinians) friar and bishop of [Phrygia](/article/en/Phrygia) whom Francis had created cardinal in 2023, took the papal name **[Leo XIV](/article/en/Pope_Leo_XIV)**, becoming the second pope from the Americas after Francis. ## Controversies and Criticisms ### Theological Disagreements #### *Amoris Laetitia* Controversy Francis's 2016 apostolic exhortation [*Amoris Laetitia*](/article/en/Amoris_Laetitia) sparked significant theological controversy, particularly regarding its approach to divorced and remarried Catholics and access to [sacraments](/article/en/Sacrament). The text called for "responsible personal and pastoral discernment" rather than categorical rules, stating: "It is important that the divorced who have entered a new union should be made to feel part of the Church." This language was interpreted by some bishops as permitting communion for remarried divorcees under certain circumstances—a reading that departed from strict [canon law](/article/en/Canon_law) requiring sexual abstinence or an annulment. In July 2017, four cardinals ([Raymond Burke](/article/en/Raymond_Burke), [Carlo Caffarra](/article/en/Carlo_Caffarra), [Walter Brandmüller](/article/en/Walter_Brandmüller), [Joachim Meisner](/article/en/Joachim_Meisner)) formally submitted five "*dubia*" (doubts) requesting yes/no clarifications from Francis regarding the exhortation's interpretation. Francis never publicly responded to these dubia, maintaining what critics called deliberate ambiguity and what supporters termed pastoral flexibility. In September 2017, a group of conservative clergy, academics, and laypeople published a "*Correctio Filialis*" ("Filial Correction"), a 25-page document accusing Francis of promoting seven heretical propositions. This represented the first formal correction of a reigning pope since 1333—an extraordinarily rare action. The controversy divided the episcopate: some bishops implemented restrictive interpretations (excluding remarried divorced from sacraments unless living in continence), while others adopted expansive interpretations (permitting sacramental access following pastoral discernment). #### *Fiducia Supplicans* and Same-Sex Blessings On 18 December 2023, Francis approved the declaration [*Fiducia Supplicans*](/article/en/Fiducia_Supplicans) from the [Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith](/article/en/Dicastery_for_the_Doctrine_of_the_Faith), permitting priests to offer "spontaneous blessings" to same-sex couples and couples in irregular situations without these constituting sacramental validation of the unions. **Controversy:** Conservative cardinals including [Gerhard Ludwig Müller](/article/en/Gerhard_Ludwig_Müller) called it "sacrilegious and blasphemous." [Cardinal Robert Sarah](/article/en/Robert_Sarah) described it as "a heresy that seriously undermines the Church." In response, 11 African bishops' conferences, represented by [Cardinal Fridolin Ambongo](/article/en/Fridolin_Ambongo), announced they would not implement the declaration in their regions. **Support:** LGBTQ advocates and progressive Catholics praised it as a meaningful pastoral opening toward inclusion, though noting its limitations regarding actual sacramental recognition of same-sex unions. #### *Traditionis Custodes* and the Latin Mass In July 2021, Francis issued the motu proprio [*Traditionis Custodes*](/article/en/Traditionis_Custodes), reversing elements of his predecessor [Benedict XVI's](/article/en/Pope_Benedict_XVI) [*Summorum Pontificum*](/article/en/Summorum_Pontificum) (2007), which had liberalized access to the [Traditional Latin Mass](/article/en/Tridentine_Mass) ([extraordinary form](/article/en/Extraordinary_form)). Under *Traditionis Custodes*: - Bishops regained authority to grant or suppress use of the Latin Mass in their dioceses - Newly ordained priests required permission to celebrate the old rite - Mass communities practicing the extraordinary form faced increased restrictions **Criticism:** Conservative prelates including Cardinals [Raymond Burke](/article/en/Raymond_Burke), [Gerhard Ludwig Müller](/article/en/Gerhard_Ludwig_Müller), and [Joseph Zen](/article/en/Joseph_Zen) opposed the decree as unnecessarily harsh and implemented with unjustifiable haste. Many traditionalist Catholics felt the restrictions violated their spiritual heritage and [Pope Benedict XVI's](/article/en/Pope_Benedict_XVI) more permissive approach. #### Document on Human Fraternity The [Document on Human Fraternity](/article/en/Document_on_Human_Fraternity) signed with Grand Imam [Ahmed al-Tayeb](/article/en/Ahmed_al-Tayeb) in Abu Dhabi (4 February 2019) attracted theological criticism, particularly its assertion that "pluralism and diversity of religions, color, sex, race, and language are the will of God in His wisdom." Catholic theologian [Chad Pecknold](/article/en/Chad_Pecknold) argued this formulation was "puzzling and potentially problematic," potentially suggesting that religious diversity itself is willed by God rather than understood as a consequence of human freedom and sin. [Bishop Athanasius Schneider](/article/en/Athanasius_Schneider) claimed Francis clarified he meant the "permissive will" of God, allowing diversity while preferring Christian unity. The interpretive ambiguity generated debate among Catholic theologians. ### Political Controversies #### Relations with Donald Trump Since 2016, Francis and [President Donald Trump](/article/en/Donald_Trump) have been in public disagreement: - During the 2016 campaign, Francis stated: "A person who thinks only of building walls, of any kind, and not of building bridges, is not a Christian." Trump responded that such criticism from a religious leader was "disgraceful." - In February 2025, as Trump began mass deportations of migrants, Francis wrote what observers described as "an extraordinary and excoriating response to US bishops," defending migrants and refugees as deserving of fraternal love. #### China Relations and Religious Freedom As discussed above, Francis's pursuit of diplomatic normalization with [China](/article/en/China) and the controversial 2018 Vatican-China agreement drew criticism from religious freedom advocates, particularly [Cardinal Joseph Zen](/article/en/Joseph_Zen), who viewed it as compromising Church independence and Catholic religious liberty for diplomatic rapprochement. #### Relations with Venezuela and Nicaragua In [Venezuela](/article/en/Venezuela), Francis declined to openly condemn [President Nicolás Maduro](/article/en/Nicolás_Maduro) despite pressure from local bishops and opposition figures, pursuing instead a mediation role that critics felt enabled authoritarianism. In [Nicaragua](/article/en/Nicaragua), tensions escalated between Francis and [President Daniel Ortega](/article/en/Daniel_Ortega), who persecuted the Catholic Church and imprisoned bishops including [Rolando Álvarez](/article/en/Rolando_Álvarez). In March 2023, Nicaragua suspended diplomatic relations with the Vatican in response to Francis's criticism of Ortega's regime as reminiscent of "communist or Hitlerian dictatorships." #### Ukraine War Neutrality As discussed extensively above, Francis's reluctance to directly condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine, his suggestions about NATO's provocative role, and his focus on dialogue rather than clear attribution of aggression frustrated many Ukrainians and Western leaders, who perceived his approach as morally ambiguous. ## Legacy and Historical Assessment As of 2025, assessments of Francis's thirteen-year pontificate remain contested along ideological lines: ### Achievements and Positive Contributions **Reformist vision:** Francis fundamentally reoriented the Church toward the peripheries—the poor, marginalized, LGBTQ persons, refugees—and elevated mercy and pastoral accompaniment as central theological values. **Institutional transformation:** Through curial reform, financial transparency initiatives, cardinal appointments, and synodal processes, he initiated structural changes toward decentralization, lay participation, and missionary outreach. **Environmental leadership:** *Laudato Si'* and subsequent writings positioned the Catholic Church as an institutional voice for climate action and ecological justice. **Interreligious dialogue:** Francis advanced unprecedented levels of dialogue with Islam, Orthodox Christianity, and other faiths, emphasizing shared values and common humanity. **Abuse accountability:** Despite inconsistencies, Francis implemented institutional reforms making mandatory reporting, victim protection, and perpetrator accountability Church policy. **Accessibility and communication:** Francis's media presence, accessible language, and personal humility made Catholicism more relatable to contemporary populations. ### Criticisms and Limitations **Theological ambiguity:** Critics argue Francis employed deliberately ambiguous language on contested issues (Amoris Laetitia, gender ideology), allowing multiple interpretations and potentially enabling doctrinal confusion. **Insufficient structural change:** While initiating reforms, Francis maintained core traditional doctrines on women's ordination, clerical celibacy, and contraception, limiting the scope of transformation some sought. **Diplomatic compromises:** His pursuit of Vatican diplomatic goals (China relations, Ukraine mediation) sometimes appeared to compromise prophetic witness on religious freedom and human rights. **Incomplete abuse response:** Despite reforms, the Church continued protecting some abusers, reassigning complicit bishops, and relying on statute of limitations defenses, failing to satisfy survivor advocates. **Declining Catholicism:** During Francis's papacy, Catholic adherence in traditionally Catholic regions ([Europe](/article/en/Europe), [Latin America](/article/en/Latin_America)) continued declining, raising questions about whether his pastoral approach effectively addressed secularization. **Age and health:** His advancing age and health challenges in final years limited his availability and effectiveness in directly driving reform. ### Comparative Historical Position Francis is likely to be remembered as a transitional pope who fundamentally altered the tone and priorities of the papal office while working within traditional institutional and doctrinal constraints. His emphasis on mercy, option for the poor, environmental stewardship, and inclusive dialogue shifted Catholic identity and practice in significant ways. Yet his reluctance to undertake more radical structural reforms (women's ordination, married clergy, contraception) and his diplomatic pragmatism disappointed those seeking more comprehensive transformation. Historical judgment may ultimately depend on whether the structural and attitudinal changes he initiated prove sustainable and generative in subsequent pontificates, or whether they represent an anomalous period of reform interrupted by more conservative successors. ## See Also - [Pope Leo XIV](/article/en/Pope_Leo_XIV) (Francis's successor) - [Pope Benedict XVI](/article/en/Pope_Benedict_XVI) (predecessor) - [Second Vatican Council](/article/en/Second_Vatican_Council) - [Society of Jesus](/article/en/Society_of_Jesus) - [Catholic Church](/article/en/Catholic_Church) - [Laudato Si'](/article/en/Laudato_Si) - [Synodality](/article/en/Synodality) - [Catholic Church sexual abuse scandal](/article/en/Catholic_Church_sexual_abuse_scandal) ## References ### Primary Sources - Papal documents and encyclicals via [Vatican.va](/article/en/Vatican) - Apostolic exhortations: *Evangelii Gaudium*, *Amoris Laetitia*, *Laudate Deum*, *Fratelli Tutti*, *Christus Vivit* - Official Vatican Press Office statements and Vatican News reports ### Secondary Sources - Allen, John L.
